titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Frank J. Cianciola papers, 1946-2007
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Lance Stuchell, 2008

did.abstract: Frank Cianciola was the Director of the Michigan Union system and played a major role in student programming and activities at the University of Michigan from 1980 to his retirement in 2007. Papers consist of correspondence, planning material, financial and budgetary records, and material produced by students at the University of Michigan, the majority of which span 1972-1998. The bulk of the collection represents Cianciola's role as Union administrator, which includes financial records and planning materials from major building renovations, and his work with the student population. The collection contains records created by Cianciola and Union administrators preceding him.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received in one accession (Donor No. 9856), February 2007.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Frank J. Cianciola papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: After receiving a B.A. in education from the University of Akron, Frank Cianciola began his career in student services by opening the Kent State University Student Center in 1973. He received his M.A in educational administration in 1978, also from the University of Akron, and moved to the University of Michigan as Director of the Michigan Union and Student Programs two years later. As director, Cianciola oversaw great changes in the Union, including the expansion and renovation of the Union building and the creation of programs intended to once again make the union a center for student life on campus.

During his tenure at Michigan, Cianciola's responsibilities expanded to include a close relationship with the student body. In 1992, he became the Associate Dean of Students. In 1999, Cianciola was named the interim Associate Vice President for Student Affairs and Dean of Students, transitioning to Senior Associate Vice President for Student Affairs in 2001, a position he held until his retirement in 2007. Through these positions, Cianciola played a major role in creating programs and policy for students and student organizations. As the liaison between student groups and the university administration, Cianciola was at the center of several controversies and major campus issues during his tenure, and had a close relationship with the Michigan Student Assembly, the University Activities Center, the University Cellar, and other student groups.

scopecontent.p: The Frank Cianciola Papers measure 17.5 linear feet and range from 1946 to 2007. The bulk of the material, however, dates from 1974 to 1998. The papers are divided into four series: Correspondence; Student Services Files; Topical Files; and Union System Administration Files.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series, 1978-2004 (1.25 linear feet) is comprised of letters and memos that cover a wide rage of topics. This series uses the basic original structure of Cianciola's filing system, with some files categorized by topic and others files from the 1980s organized chronologically. This series includes communication with University of Michigan administrators and correspondence centered on specific student activities and programming. The other series in this collection also contain correspondence that relate to their subject matter.

did.unittitle: Associate Dean of Students, "Same Page" Correspondence 1995-1996

scopecontent.p: The Student Services Files, 1972-2006 (7 linear feet) series is divided into three subseries: Minority Student Services, 1971-2005 (.75 linear feet) Programming, 1974-2006 (3 linear feet) and Student Groups, 1972-2006 (3.25 linear feet). These records represent Cianciola's role in providing programs directed at the student population, facilitating the work of student groups, and setting university policy affecting student life. The Minority Student Services subseries includes records on the administration of the William Monroe Trotter Multicultural Center, as well as programs and studies focusing on campus diversity and the university's relationship with minority students. The Programming subseries includes records from Student Organizations and Programs (SOAP), which developed student leadership and organizations; and the Office of Major Events, which staged large-scale concerts and shows for the general public. The Student Groups subseries represents Cianciola's work with student organizations, interest groups, and social policy. This subseries includes material from the Michigan Student Assembly, records concerning "Hash Bash" and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, material documenting the sometimes contentious relationship between the administration and the student-managed University Cellar bookstore, and records surrounding the re-drafting of the controversial social events policy.

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files, 1974-2007 (2.75 linear feet) consists of material dealing with disparate subject matter, including the effects of alcohol on campus, Union fundraising material, and minority groups and issues.

did.unittitle: "A University Community Approach to Alcohol and Drugs" Report 1991
Mental Health Service for Students Work Group, General 2001-2005
Mental Health Service for Students Work Group, Report 2003

scopecontent.p: The Union System Administration Files, 1946-2006 (6.5 linear feet) consists of four subseries: Facilities, 1956-2007 (3.25 linear feet) Financial, 1946-1991 (.75 linear feet) Franchises and Retail, 1971-1994 (.5 linear feet) and Planning and Reports, 1968-1999 (2 linear feet). These records represent the management of the university Union system, including facilities management and fiscal operations. This series contains a large portion of material created by union administrations prior to Cianciola's arrival in 1980. The Facilities subseries contains records pertaining to the physical assets of the Union system including the Michigan League, Union, and Pierpont Commons buildings, and the common areas of the university, including the Diag. Of note are records and construction plans from several major renovations of the Michigan Union, and the policy governing the use of the Diag. The Facility subseries is organized around each facility or area. The Financial subseries contain much of the older records in the collection. The Financial and the Planning and Reports subseries are organized chronologically.
